div.p:
8 SundayFeb.y 8th 1818 Miss Baillie’s letter will not be quite intelligible to you my dear Aunt without a note from ME.—You must know that just after you left Dublin there appeared in some Dublin paper a let- ter taken from a Scotch paper called the Craftsman con- taining a sort of critique or comparision between the novels of miss E and of the author of Waverley &c—I [deletion]was[/deletion] believing as I always have done that Walter Scott if not the sole author at
least the directing soul of those works, and being really fond of him & grateful for his kindness to me was particularly vexed to see this insidious compari son instituted between us for in the course of the de- fence of miss E which this purported to be many things were said about him in which I should be very sorry he could think that under hand or any way I had any concern—I wrote to my friend Joanna express- ing these feelings—
Now the first part of her letter will be intelligence but you will come to a story about Sir Alexr Gordon whh requires an explanatory preface— All Dublin you know was talk ing over the long canvassed question Is W. Scott or not the author of the 3 unclaimed novels?— Now one of the Miss Hamilton’s told Harriet B who told me the following anecdote. That Sir Alex Gordon had declared to her his conviction of W. Scott being the author because before the publica tion of Guy Mannering he the said Sir Alexr went
to one of his tenants houses where he met W. Scott & where first such a scene passed as is painted in Guy Mannering at the funeral of [unclear]Steeney[/unclear]— The said Sir Alexr further declared that when he again met Walter Scott after the pub lication of Guy Mannering & reminded him or was going to remind him of this circumstance Walter Scott put his finger on his lips in token of silence & secrecy— It appears you will see that the knight would have done better to be silent Ys affectionately Maria Edgeworth
